pullRequest.body:
A starting point to define [dinatural transformations](https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/dinatural+transformation).

This is my first PR so style comments and improvements are very welcome!

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I shall have a look at the details of this PR later. As this is not a most standard categorical notion, I am only wondering whether you have plans to use that for future works, and if so you could add a `## Future works` section in this file.
Maybe we should first merge #8150 first and then remove the old `op_prod`.

> Overall, this looks good to me, especially for a first PR! After some modifications, it should be fine. My only reluctance about merging this PR is whether we have active plans to use these definitions (is it related to coends? etc).

Yes, I'm planning to use these for coends shortly after! I have some material about coends ready to PR soon :-)
I talked to @iwilare via DM in zulip and she gave me the go ahead to finish off this PR

### PR summary

#### Import changes

No significant changes to the import graph

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ DinatTrans`
`+ DinatTrans.compNatTrans`
`+ DinatTrans.op`
`+ DinatTrans.precompNatTrans`
`+ Functor.diop`
`+ biop`
`+ comp_app₂`
`+ comp_app₃`
`+ naturality_app_app`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

Overall, this looks good to me, especially for a first PR! After some modifications, it should be fine. My only reluctance about merging this PR is whether we have active plans to use these definitions (is it related to coends? etc).

In `mathlib`, the preferred spelling for "bifunctor" are functors `F G : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ C ⥤ D` to a category of functors. Could you consider using this instead? (This may make easier the formulation of `dinaturality` also.)

I tried at first using that, but the actions on objects and morphisms become a bit complicated (I have no idea how to express it without an ad-hoc helper to compose twice to act on the first morphism and then the second), and most importantly stray from the usual category-theoretic notation... I found no other definition for `Bifunctors` other than [this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Products/Bifunctor.lean), which seems to be using the product definition along with [`hom`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Functor/Hom.lean).

There is little API for "bifunctor" as functors from a product category because there is a focus on functors to a category of functors. I do not see any problem with the following:
```lean
structure DinatTrans (F G : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ C ⥤ D) where
  app (X : C) : (F.obj (op X)).obj X ⟶ (G.obj (op X)).obj X
  dinaturality {X Y : C} (f : X ⟶ Y) :
    (F.map f.op).app X ≫ app X ≫ (G.obj (op X)).map f =
      (F.obj (op Y)).map f ≫ app Y ≫ (G.map f.op).app Y
```
In order to develop the API using this definition, it may become convenient to use some lemmas like `NatTrans.app_naturality` or `NatTrans.naturality_app`.
I switched to this representation by defining some helpers in Bifunctor, let me know what you think!

```suggestion
    dsimp
    rw [Category.assoc, Category.assoc, ← α.naturality, δ.dinaturality_assoc f, ← α.naturality]
```
We should refrain from using "nonterminal simp". If we have to do some `rw` after a plain `simp`, we should use the output of `simp?`. (Note that in order to make my suggestion work, the attribute `reassoc` should be added to the `dinaturality` lemma.

I copied the attribute setting from `NatTrans` to apply the suggestion, this works pretty nicely! Should `%reassoc_of` only be used only when an equation comes "externally", for example as assumption? (rather than coming internally as data of a structure)
(Is there a general way to get the output of `simp?` in terms of `rw`? For example here `simp` uses it twice.)
I also fixed the other definition with `erw` in the same style, but I don't see why `erw` is necessary in this case rather than just `rw`.
Yes, `reassoc_of%` should be mostly used only on terms are assumptions in the local context. Otherwise, it is better to fix the attributes of the lemma and add the `reassoc` attribute to it.

As this is a definition, we should not use `_` in the name but use a suitable capitalisation like `natComp`, even though here I would prefer `precompNatTrans` (or just `precomp`) because this is in the `DinatTrans` namespace. Also, you should insert a line with `@[simps]`.
I added `@[simps]` to each definition for composition along with `op`, not sure if they are all good ideas...

```suggestion
@[simps]
```
By using `simps` instead of `simp`, we do not automatically simplify terms like `F.diop`, but only `F.diop.obj`, `F.diop.map`, etc.
Added `@[simps!]` as per the warning.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (H.obj2 C₁ D₁ ⟶ H.obj2 C₂ D₂) := (H.map f).app _ ≫ (H.obj C₂).map g ```
The import are not optimal: you should remove from the list the files that are imported by other imports.

This seems like a good idea to me, but it has to be an abbreviation, and I would suggest using small indices (type "\2" is VSCode):
```suggestion
abbrev obj₂ (H : C ⥤ D ⥤ E) (A : C) (B : D) : E := (H.obj A).obj B
```
I left `abbrev` for all expressions that are not constructed with a composition, but wouldn't it be better to hide the implementation details of `obj₂?`?

I think we should keep `obj₂`  as an abbrev. For the other definitions, I think the best solution would be to have also ` map₂` and ` map₃` as abbreviations (maybe even with `@[reducible]`?), and to have `naturality_app` as a global simp lemma (I hope this would not break too many things...), so that `naturality₂` could be proved `by simp` (and thus become not essential, even though we may keep it as a nonsimp lemma). And, in order to get `naturality₃` essentially automatically `by simp`, it would be sufficient to introduce another simp lemma `naturality_app_app`.

I thought `abbrev` was already `@[reducible]`? Maybe I'm misremembering. Regardless I've switched these to `abbrev`s. I don't think naturality is "directed" enough to be a good simp lemma; it seems likely we'll want to rewrite in different directions depending on the natural transformation (I think the `@[simp]` on `naturality₂, naturality₃` is a bit sketchy for the same reason, but I'm not going to try and change it in this PR)

Hm, if we mark `map₂, map₃` as `abbrev` then `reassoc` interacts very poorly with lemmas that mention `map₂`, `map₃` (eg `dinaturality_assoc`). Making them reducible makes sense if we expect that lemmas about `map₂, map₃` should be proved by reducing everything to `map` and using automation. But I'm not sure this is what we should design for? When working with bifunctors/profunctors we're likely going to want to think of `map₂` as an atom. I've reverted the change to `abbrev`s because I think it's more trouble than it's worth.

In monoidal categories, `f ⊗ g` is thought as `(f ▷ _) ≫ (_ ◁ g)` since the refactor. Then, as a matter of consistency, I think that if it is possible not to use a `def`, and use `map₂` only as a reducible abbrev, this is the direction we should go.

Do we have analogues of ▷ and ◁ for the action of a bifunctor? If we add those then I think we could break up dinaturality like `μ_natural_left`/`μ_natural_right`. As is simp plays extremely poorly with `map₂`
Or I guess the analogue is just mapping with an identity argument. I'll try and see if dinaturality can be broken into two cases like I said
I would say it is ` (H.map f).app D₁` and `(H.obj C₂).map g` which are in the definitions of `map₂`.

```suggestion
@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
lemma naturality₂ {H G : C ⥤ D ⥤ E} (α : H ⟶ G) {X Y X' Y'} (f : X ⟶ X') (g : Y ⟶ Y') :
```
Even though they are definitionally equal, I think it is better to use `H ⟶ G` instead of `NatTrans H G`.
I agree, done! I can change `naturality₂` and `naturality₃` but I can't do the same for `app₂` and `app₃`, how come?

I just noticed that using `H ⟶ G` instead of `NatTrans` does not allow to use `α.naturality₂` as field notation... I guess it's because it needs instance resolution to solve the hom notation, so it does not include the definition as part of the fields of `NatTrans`, or something along these lines.

It is pretty awkward to not be able to use dot notation. I've kept the `NatTrans` argument while in the `NatTrans` namespace. In fact, I think `NatTrans.naturality_app` should probably have `NatTrans` argument so that it can be used with dot notation
Then, please check that the simp lemmas work with `H ⟶ G`, and revert to `H ⟶ G` in case it does not.

If `map₂` is an abbrev we can't have `naturality₂`, `naturality₃` as simp lemmas (because they aren't in simp normal form). So this is vacuously true but I'm not sure the current state of things (no simp lemmas) is good. I think your suggestion to mark `naturality_app` and `naturality_app_app` as `simp` is a good one, and if we do so the following works (so presumably simp is able to determine that lemmas with a `NatTrans` argument apply to something of type `H ⟶ G`).
```
@[reassoc (attr:=simp)]
theorem naturality_app_app {G H : C ⥤ D ⥤ E ⥤ F} (T : NatTrans G H) (Z : E) 
    {X₁ Y₁ : C} {X₂ Y₂ : D} (f : X₁ ⟶ Y₁) (g : X₂ ⟶ Y₂) :
    (G.map f).app₂ X₂ Z ≫ ((G.obj Y₁).map g).app Z ≫ T.app₃ Y₁ Y₂ Z =
      T.app₃ X₁ X₂ Z ≫ (H.map₂ f g).app Z := by
  rw [naturality_app, ← Category.assoc, ← comp_app₂,
    naturality, comp_app₂, Category.assoc]
  rfl

example {G H : C ⥤ D ⥤ E ⥤ F} (T : G ⟶ H) (Z : E) {X₁ Y₁ : C}
    {X₂ Y₂ : D} (f : X₁ ⟶ Y₁) (g : X₂ ⟶ Y₂) :
    (G.map f).app₂ X₂ Z ≫ ((G.obj Y₁).map g).app Z ≫ T.app₃ Y₁ Y₂ Z =
      T.app₃ X₁ X₂ Z ≫ (H.map₂ f g).app Z := by
  simp
```

Maybe we can plan to mark `naturality_app` as a global simp lemmas after this PR?

> Maybe we can plan to mark `naturality_app` as a global simp lemmas after this PR?

I think this could be attempted in this PR.

For the rest, the abbreviations `app₂` and `app₃` are ok, but I think we should essentially get rid of `map₂` and `map₃`, and rely mostly on the already existing automation, with `naturality_app` as a global simp lemma and a new `naturality_app_app` in the following version:
```lean
@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
lemma naturality_app_app
    {G H : C ⥤ D ⥤ E ⥤ F} (T : NatTrans G H) (Y : D) (Z : E) {X X' : C} (f : X ⟶ X') :
    ((G.map f).app Y).app Z ≫ ((T.app X').app Y).app Z =
      ((T.app X).app Y).app Z ≫ ((H.map f).app Y).app Z :=
  congr_app (NatTrans.naturality_app T Y f) Z
```

Then, your version of `naturality_app_app` can be proven by `simp`.

I'm building with `naturality_app` marked as simp right now and it doesn't seem to break anything, and I like this version of `naturality_app_app`. However I feel mixed about removing `map₂` and `map₃`. As is they play very poorly with simp, but it's going to be really annoying to write out the definition of `map₂` every time you work with a bifunctor. I think for right now I'll remove them, but if/when we get around to adding profunctors and (co)ends I think this might need to be revisited

I've pushed this version of the code. By the way, could `naturality_app`, `naturality_app_app`, `naturality_app_app_app`, ... be a `simproc`? I don't know enough about `simproc`s to say if this would be a good idea

```suggestion
```
This can be done at declaration time.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [← NatTrans.naturality₂] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [← NatTrans.naturality₂_assoc] ```

Untested, but it should a `rfl` lemma, so that users may do `dsimp [comp_app₂]`
```suggestion
    (α ≫ β).app₂ X Y = α.app₂ X Y ≫ β.app₂ X Y := rfl
```
(Untested: this one may be a good `simp` lemma.)
(Same for `comp_app₃`.)
Good points, I've tagged them as `simp`. Using `@[reassoc, simp]` over `@[reassoc (attr := simp)]` is intentional, the linter complains about the latter
Yes, `@[simp, reassoc]` is standard when compositions appear only in the RHS.

```suggestion
functors `F G : Cᵒᵖ ⥤ C ⥤ D` which depend both covariantly and contravariantly
```

```suggestion
  app (X : C) : F.obj₂ (op X) X ⟶ G.obj₂ (op X) X
```
Same for the other field.

For one-liners, I believe this is the preferred syntax:
```suggestion
/-- Post-composition with a natural transformation. -/
```

We are supposed to put spaces around infix operators:
```suggestion
@[reassoc (attr := simp)]
```

pullRequest.title: feat(CategoryTheory): add dinatural transformations
